content.description: Sit start. Begin in the cave and pull on the first big ledge. Use crimps and shallow cracks until you can get your feet on, then float up the slabby finish.
content.location: Top out ends on a trail that loops back down with some easy scrambling.

content.description:
This staircase is easy ground up a corner all the way up to a big ledge right before the topout. Minor crux between the highest step and the first ledge. 

  Good for beginner boulderers, but still a highball compared to most Alabama bouldering, so be careful. Several thin trees are in the landing area so falling not recommended.
content.location: Trails run from the top of the rockwall to either side. Easy and safe hike off.

content.description:
This face has ample feet and easy hands halfway up. After that, you can drift left to the chimney or make committing moves up the face. 

  Loose shelf in the chimney, check with your hands before pulling on shelves.
content.protection: Pad and spotter. Dangerous spike stump at the bottom, be careful!
content.location: Walk down the trail to the left or right after topping out.

content.description: Flaky arete all the way to the top.
content.location: Walk down either left or right on the trail.

content.description: Big foot holds go up to sharp flakes. The route's namesake is a round flake that's sharp on all sides, halfway up.
content.location: After topping out, walkout down the trail to the left or the right.

content.description: Super fun route! Sit start in small cave, work on right side to mantle overtop
content.location: Arrowhead trail right before large rock faces

content.description:
Vertical cracks and seams go all the way up. Some sharp crimps are available if you don't wanna stick your hand into the dark holes. 

  The tree is behind you to the left. It's possible to stem all the way up using the tree, but that's cheating! Lean right to turn the cracks into side-pulls and don't let your butt dab the bark.
content.location: Walk off the trail at the top, to the right or the left.

content.description: Tough start. Needs cleaning but all around good route. Probably the best route on arrowhead trail. Could probably be done as a boulder without protection but I wouldn’t recommend it. The route is just to the left of the picture on the other side of the tree. Look for the smiley in the rock and you’re at the right place. Not in the crack.
content.location: You’ll know the crag when you see it. Look for the smiley in the rock and go around the left side of the tree right next to it.

content.description:
This section of Monte Sano is accessed from the South Monte Sano Trailhead. It connects to several trails and has free, but limited parking. 

  Arrowhead Trail cuts through a 20-30 foot high rock passageway, primarily Limestone with sharp flakes and plentiful horizontal ledges and cracks. 

  While adventurous people are sure to have scrambled these rocks in the past, no documentation for them exists. If FA or route name info becomes known, please message the page author to correct them.
